title: Credit Suisse's role in the Greensill Capital crisis

Greensill: how much did Credit Suisse know?

All Thomas Gottstein wanted was a “clean slate”.

The chief executive of Credit Suisse, who replaced the ousted Tidjane Thiam in February 2020, told the FT as much after spending a tumultuous year navigating the fallout from a corporate spying scandal and run-ins with alleged frauds at Luckin Coffee and Wirecard.

But another crisis was building in the backdrop to smudge up whichever parts of the slate he'd managed to polish off.

We're of course talking about the saga of Greensill Capital, the now collapsed supply chain finance group founded by Australian financier Lex Greensill.

At the start of March, Credit Suisse suspended $10bn of funds linked to the SoftBank-backed company after it found out that some of the insurance on Greensill's invoice-backed loans would not renew.

DD regulars know what happens next (for those that don't, catch up on all of the FT's Greensill coverage here). Greensill, and one of its biggest clients, the metals magnate Sanjeev Gupta, were left scrambling.

It's important to point out here that Lex Greensill and Credit Suisse go way back. The financier was a big private-banking client of the Swiss lender, and his company also held relationships with its investment banking and asset management arms.

Last year, the bank even lent Greensill $160m, of which $140m was outstanding before $50m was repaid this week. The loan was made even though it was initially rejected by internal risk managers. 

Now in damage control mode, the bank has drafted former UBS asset management head Ulrich Körner to lead its asset management division, replacing Eric Varvel, who will stay on at the group in other roles, and has placed three senior executives on temporary leave.

The question still remains as to how much Credit Suisse's top ranks knew of Greensill's curious accounting methods.

Bonuses for the entire executive board were 30 per cent lower this year, and the bank said it might also consider clawing back previously paid bonuses as it assesses the magnitude of the financial hit levelled by Greensill.

Are these signs that, after years of making headlines, the scandal-hit Swiss institution could be entering a new era of accountability?

It won't be too much of a bother to the bank's chair Urs Rohner either way, whose compensation remained at SFr4.7m for his final year in the role, despite presiding over corporate espionage, heavy losses and the Greensill affair.

Further complicating things for Credit Suisse is the fact that its ailing Greensill-tied funds never received an emergency cash injection from SoftBank late last year as intended, Rob and DD's Arash Massoudi report. 

Oh, and before we forget, one more Greensill bombshell to leave you with before you head into the weekend: former UK prime minister and Greensill adviser David Cameron lobbied the UK government to increase the group's access to state-backed emergency Covid-19 loan schemes just months before its collapse.

A landmark shareholder victory in corporate Japan

Earlier this week, DD broke down the mechanics of Thursday's big shareholder showdown as Toshiba faced off against an unprecedented cast of foreign investors (from notoriously combative activists to the world's biggest sovereign wealth fund).

Shareholder proposals have never made much headway in Japan, especially when they target the management of big household companies. 

But Thursday's stunning shareholder vote changed all that, writes the FT's Leo Lewis from Tokyo.

Effissimo, the secretive Singapore-based fund that broke cover last week to talk to the FT, not only forced Toshiba to hold an EGM the conglomerate desperately wanted to avoid, but actually won. 

Its demand for an independent investigation into what Effissimo and others see as suspicious circumstances surrounding Toshiba's 2020 AGM, turned out to be something that big global funds keen to project their ESG images found themselves readily able to support. 

A separate proposal from US fund Farallon did not succeed.

Now an investigation into the “dark arts” campaign conducted around Toshiba's 2020 AGM will take place and it may or may not dig up something juicy; in any event, this was a humiliating defeat for Toshiba's management, and could hasten the downfall of its chief executive, Nobuaki Kurumatani. 

The investigation itself will be groundbreaking but matters less than the fact that it has arisen from a supremely high-profile exercise in shareholders' rights in Japan. 

Pinduoduo's curious succession story

Colin Huang, founder of Chinese ecommerce group Pinduoduo, is stepping away with billions to his name six years after starting the company which currently boasts a $180bn market cap, writes the FT's Ryan McMorrow from Beijing. 

Huang said he's turning over voting rights for his 29 per cent stake to the board and pledged to not sell any shares for three years before handing the reins to Chen Lei, who happens to be one of his university schoolmates from the University of Wisconsin-Madison.

Aside from working for Huang, Lei only lists a series of internships at Google, Yahoo and IBM in his executive bio. (Google told the FT it has no record of his time at the company.) 

Chen has been at Huang's side for the past decade, a loyal lieutenant as Huang set up a series of ecommerce ventures that operate from completely unmarked offices in Shanghai. The dozens of apps and sites in the building, with names like Vova, Azazie and Floryday, sell Chinese goods into Europe and the US.

While they don't directly compete with Pinduoduo, the company has told its US investors nothing about them. 

Part of the reason may be that Huang has tapped a series of loyal stand-ins like Chen and a 69-year-old woman from rural China to register his shareholdings with Chinese authorities. 

Huang even took the unusual step of turning over control of Pinduoduo's main Chinese operating entity, known as a variable interest entity, to Chen before its IPO. Most other Chinese tech executives have kept tight control over their onshore companies.
